Submodules of an A-module M are defined similarly to subspaces in vector spaces, where a submodule N of M is a subset that is closed under the operations of M.
An element x of an A-module M is called a torsion element if there exists an element a in A-{0} such that a.x = 0.
Does the concept of a/an Submodule need to be defined for a definition of a/an Torsion element to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a torsion element in an A-module M does not inherently require the concept of a submodule. A torsion element is defined solely based on the existence of an element a in the ring A (excluding zero) such that the product of a and the element x in the module M equals zero. This definition focuses on individual elements of the module and their interaction with elements of the ring A.\n\nOn the other hand, a submodule is a subset of a module that itself forms a module under the same operations. The definition of a submodule involves understanding subsets and closure properties but does not directly impact the definition of a torsion element. The concept of a torsion element can be fully understood and applied without any reference to submodules. Therefore, the concept of a submodule is not necessary for the definition of a torsion element to make sense.
